examples: She knows all and sees all .
All of Jones’s maneuvers to trounce Kennedy.
All is not well at home lately.
Those who think they know it all are annoying to those of us who do.
A good time was had by all (of you/us/them).
I've got three children, of whom all are studying medicine.
All that was left was a small pile of ash.
We ate potatoes and ziti .... that's all .

definitions.definition: Used after who , what , where , how and similar words, either without changing their meaning, or indicating that one expects that they cover more than one element, e.g. that "Who all attended?" is more than one person. ( Some dialects only allow this to follow some words and not others. )
definitions.label_groups: chiefly Southern US , South Midland US , Midland US , Scotland , Northern Ireland , India

secondary_definitions: ( chiefly Southern US , South Midland US , Midland US , Scotland , Northern Ireland , India ) Used after who , what , where , how and similar words, either without changing their meaning, or indicating that one expects that they cover more than one element, e.g. that "Who all attended?" is more than one person. ( Some dialects only allow this to follow some words and not others. )
